analytic.title: This article has been accepted for inclusion in a future issue of this journal. Content is final as presented, with the exception of pagination

biblStruct.note: received February 8, 2015; revised November 5, 2015; accepted November 8, 2015.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: In this paper, the optimal output regulation problem for partially model-free heterogeneous linear multiagent systems with disturbance generated by an exosystem is addressed by using adaptive dynamic programming and double compensator method. The topology graph for the information exchange of the agents has a spanning tree. The dynamic of individual agent is assumed to be nonidentical and of different dimensions. One distributed compensator is designed to deal with the nonidentical agents, and the other compensator is used to handle the optimal performance index. By constructing the double compensator, the distributed feedback control laws are designed to make the output of each agent synchronize with the reference output and minimize the energy of the output error simultaneously. To overcome the lack of the dynamics knowledge of each agent, a novel online policy iteration algorithm is developed to obtain the optimal feedback gain matrix. Finally, two examples are presented to illustrate the effectiveness of our results.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: A GROUP of autonomous agents, coordinating with each other via communication or sensing networks, can perform certain challenging tasks which cannot be well accomplished by a single agent. Therefore, coordination control and synchronization problems have been paid much attention in systems and control. It is motivated by many applications in cooperative unmanned air vehicles [1], scheduling of automated highway systems [2], tracking [3]- [6], flocking of multiple autonomous agents [7], [8], and microgrids [9]. The essential problem of coordination control is how to design a distributed algorithm such that a team of agents reaches an agreement on their states, or their outputs by using local information exchange, which is generally restricted to be a communication graph. Algebraic graph theory has been successfully applied to establish conditions under which cooperative control is completed.

The issue of synchronization is linked to many other problems in different fields, such as computer science and learning algorithm, biology, and sociology [10]- [27]. However, in recent years, a lot of researchers have started to analyze the synchronization problem from control theoretic perspective. A creative transformation was used in [10], such that the original plant is first augmented into a new descriptor system, and a novel augmented sliding mode observer is presented for the augmented system. All the autonomous systems, which are termed multiagent systems, could interact by exchanging information with their neighbors to achieve synchronization. In such studies, integration of dynamical systems and graph theory provides powerful tools to formulate the synchronization problem in multiagent systems. Output synchronization of networked multiagent systems was studied in [11] by employing a strongly connected graph. Design methods for interconnection control laws that ensure synchronization among identical systems were addressed in [12]. The problem has lately been extended to the case that the agents have heterogeneous matching uncertainties in [15]. Then, Grip et al. [16] studied the synchronization problem in heterogeneous networks based on setting the control input of a single root agent to zero and letting the remaining agents synchronize to the root agent. Wang et al. [17], Liang et al. [18], and Su and Huang [19] designed feedback control laws for the plant so that the outputs of all the agents not only reach synchronization but also track a reference signal (and/or rejects a disturbance) produced by an external generator or an exogenous system. Output regulation method was used in [17] and [18] based on internal model method in solving the linear multiagent systems with identical dynamics. Linear quadratic regulator (LQR) method was used in [20] to solve the optimal synchronization problem. The performance index was considered in [28] which showed that unbounded synchronization regions that achieve synchronization on arbitrary digraphs containing a spanning tree can be guaranteed by using LQR equation at each node. Leader-based synchronization was given in [29] by adaptive dynamic programming (ADP) method. An inverse optimal method was used in [26] to solve the globally optimal leader-following and leaderless multiagent systems.

The aim of optimal output regulation problem of multiagent systems is to design distributed feedback control laws such that the output of each agent synchronizes to the reference output and the energy of the output error is minimized simultaneously. The system dynamic was known in nearly all the references in solving the optimal regulation of multiagent systems. However, the dynamics of the multiagent systems are hard to obtain in common situations. An adaptive method was used in [30]- [33] to handle the uncertain nonlinear system. However, ADP technique is proved to be an effective way of solving to solve the optimal control for uncertain systems. In general, the performance index in optimal output regulation problem is expressed as the H 2 norm of the output error to minimize this performance is very challenging since it contains a cross-product term. This performance index arises naturally in many situations that include: 1) the theory of the second variation and neighboring optimal trajectories; 2) the case where the state and the control are subject to a linear constraint [34]; or 3) the optimal control for the output synchronization problems where the H 2 norm of the output signal is minimized. To the best of our knowledge, policy iteration (PI) algorithms that obtain controllers which converge to optimal solutions for partially unknown systems with respect to a given quadratic performance index with cross-product term have generally not been developed.
Motivated by the above facts, in this paper, we study optimal output regulation for partially model-free agents. The main contributions are shown as follows.

1) Output regulation problem for multiagent systems has been proposed in many works [17], [18], [35] without considering the cost function. However, to the best of our knowledge, optimal control strategy applied for this problem has few results. The main contribution of this paper is to introduce a novel double compensator approach to formally design a dynamic feedback controller (the consensus algorithm) and to address the optimal output regulation problem for heterogeneous multiagent systems. 2) The system dynamics considered in almost all existing results is known, i.e., the gain matrices could be obtained by using the system matrices directly. This paper describes the partially model-free agents and solves the optimal output regulation problem of heterogeneous multiagent systems by ADP method for the first time. 3) Moreover, compared with the optimal problem in [28] and [29], an advantage of this paper is that the influence of cross-product term among the performance indices is considered. A novel online PI algorithm is developed for this case to solve the optimal output regulation problem. The optimal feedback gain can be directly obtained by learning the states of the argument system in real time without requirement of model identification, which will lead to unacceptable computational complexity for nonidentical multiagent systems. The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, some basic knowledge about graph theory and infinite horizon optimal control problem is described. In Section III, optimal output regulation for partially modelfree heterogeneous linear multiagent systems is given.
An online PI algorithm is shown in Section IV and the convergence proof is also given. At last, two examples are given to substantiate the theoretical results.

div.head: II. PRELIMINARIES A. Graph Theory
div.p: Some basic knowledge about graph theory is described as follows (for more details, one can refer to [36]).
The network formed by multiagent systems can always be represented by a digraph. Let G = (V , E , A ) be a weighted directed graph which is composed by a vertex set
div.formula: V = {v 0 , v 1 , v 2 , . . . , v N }, an edge set E = {e i j = (v i , v j )} ⊂ V ×V ,
div.p: and a weighted adjacency matrix A = [a i j ] with nonnegative adjacency elements a i j . An edge (v i , v j ) in graph G means that the agent v i receives information from agent v j , and v i is said to be the father of node v j and v j is the child of the node v i . a i j = 1 if and only if (v i , v j ) ∈ E ; other else, a i j = 0. The set of neighbors of agent v i is denoted by
div.formula: N i = {v j ∈ V : (v i , v j ) ∈ E }. A path from v i to v j in the digraph G is a sequence of edges (v i , v i 1 ), (v i 1 , v i 2 ), . . . , (v i m , v j ) with distinct nodes i k , k = 1, . . . , m,
div.p: and v i is said to be reachable from node v j . If v i = v j , then the path is called a loop. If a node is reachable from every other node of the digraph, then it says the digraph G contains a spanning tree.
The in-degree and out-degree of node v i are defined as follows:
div.formula: deg in (v i ) = N j =1 a i j , deg out (v i ) = N j =1 a j i .
div.p: The degree matrix D = diag{d 1 , d 2 , . . . d N } is a diagonal matrix, whose diagonal elements are given as
div.formula: d i = deg in (v i ).
div.p: Correspondingly, the Laplacian matrix L with the directed graph G is defined as L ii = d i and L i j = -a i j .

The graph G is used to model the communication topologies. In this paper, v 0 is used to describe the leader node or the exosystem. Subgraph G s with node {v 1 , v 2 , . . . , v N } is used to describe the N agents. Node v 0 could be detected by the other agents but it cannot access information from the other agents. Therefore, the Laplacian matrix with the directed graph G is defined as

in which H = A 0 + L s , A 0 = diag{a 10 , a 20 , . . . , a N0 }, and L s is the Laplacian matrix of subgraph G s . Assumption 1: The digraph G contains no loop, and has a spanning tree with v 0 as its root.

Lemma 1 [37]: Zero is an eigenvalue of L with 1 as a right eigenvector and all nonzero eigenvalues have positive real parts. Furthermore, zero is a simple eigenvalue of L if and only if G has a directed spanning tree.

Note that the Laplace matrix L in (1) has only one zero eigenvalue if G has a directed spanning tree and node v 0 as its root. Therefore, we can obtain that all the eigenvalues of H have positive real parts.
We can always label the subsystem G s such that i > j if (v i , v j ) ∈ E . Therefore, if the graph G contains no loop, the matrix H is the upper triangular matrix with diagonal element d i > 0.

div.head: B. Optimal Control With Respect to Quadratic Cost With Cross-Product Term
div.p: The purpose of this paper is to solve the optimal control problem by PI method without using the information of the system internal dynamics. Some basic knowledge about infinite horizon optimal control problem required for the proofs of our main results is shown as follows.

The linear system has widely applications in the real word, such as the operation of communication satellite, the balance of the levels of liquids in chemical plants, which is shown in [38]. Let a dynamic system be described as
div.formula: ẋ(t) = Ax(t) + Bu(t), x(0) = x 0 y(t) = Cx(t) + Du(t) (2)
div.p: where The infinite horizon optimal control problem is posed as the following minimization problem. For any given initial condition x(0) = 0, find an optimal control law u such that the output energy
div.formula: J (x 0 , u(t)) = ∞ 0 y(t) T y(t)dt (3
div.p: is minimized. Remark 1: According to [39], Assumptions 2 and 3 can guarantee the reasonability of the performance index (3) and also make the optimal control problem solvable.
For the dynamic (2) with performance index (3), classical results on optimality state that the solution of optimal problem can be obtained by forming the Hamiltonian equation [40]

div.head: H (x(t), u(t)) = y(t) T y(t) + x(t) T (A T P + P A)x(t)
div.p: + 2x(t) T P Bu(t) (4) in which P is a symmetric positive definite matrix. The optimal control is obtained in the form of
div.formula: u * (t) = -(D T D) -1 (D T C + B T P)x(t)(5)
div.p: by calculating
div.formula: ∇ u(t ) (H (x(t), u(t))) = 2D T Cx(t) + 2D T Du(t) + 2B T Px(t) = 0( 6 )
div.p: where ∇ u(t ) ( * ) denotes the gradient of function * with respect to u(t). Substituting the optimal control law u * (t) into (4), and according to the optimal control theory, one gets
div.formula: x(t) T (C T C + 2C T DK + K T D T DK + A T P + P A + 2P B K )x(t) = 0 ( 7 ) in which K = -(D T D) -1 (D T C + B T P)
div.p: is the optimal control gain matrix. Note that
div.formula: x(t) T (2C T DK + 2P B K )x(t) = x(t) T (C T DK + K T D T C + P B K + K T B T P)x(t) 2C T DK + 2P B K = -2(D T C + B T P) T (D T D) -1 (D T C + B T P) = -2K T D T DK.
div.p: Thus, the Riccati equation corresponding to (4) has the following equivalent forms:
div.formula: (A + B K ) T P + P(A + B K ) + (C + DK ) T (C + DK ) = 0 (8
A T P + P A + C T C -(D T C + B T P) T (D T D) -1 (D T C + B T P) = 0.(9)
div.p: Therefore, according to Assumptions 1-3, A + B K is stable, and P is the observability Gramian of the matrix pair
div.formula: (C + DK, A + B K ).
div.p: Employing the Lyapunov candidate V (x(t)) = x(t) T Px(t) for dynamic system (2), and taking the derivative of V (x(t)) along the solution of (2), yields
div.formula: V (x(t)) = x(t) T ((A + B K ) T P + P(A + B K ))x(t) = -x(t) T (C + DK ) T (C + DK )x(t) = -y(t) T y(t). (10
div.p: Then, integrating both sides of the aforementioned equation, we obtain
div.formula: ∞ 0 y(t) T y(t)dt = x T 0 Px 0 . (11
div.p: Thus, the minimum output energy for any given initial state x 0 is given by x T 0 Px 0 , where P is called the optimal kernel matrix.

div.head: III. OPTIMAL OUTPUT REGULATION FOR NONIDENTICAL AGENTS A. Problem Formulations
div.p: Consider N + 1 nodes distributed on communication graph G , and the N nonidentical agents described as
div.formula: ẋi (t) = A i x i (t) + B i u i (t) + E i ω(t), x i (0) = x i0 y i (t) = C i x i (t) + D i u i (t), i = 1, 2, . . . , N(12)
div.p: in which x i0 , i = 1, 2, . . . , N are the initial conditions, x i ∈ R n i is the state and the measured output y i ∈ R p i , and u i ∈ R m i is the consensus protocol to be designed later. Suppose that the pair (A i , B i , C i ) is stabilizable and detectable, and D i has full column rank, i.e., D T i D i is invertible. E i ω is the disturbance of the i th agent to be rejected. ω is generated by the following system which is called exosystem:
div.formula: ω(t) = Sω(t), ω(0) = ω 0 y ri (t) = Q i ω(t) (13
div.p: where ω ∈ R q is the exosystem's state, Q i ∈ R p i ×q and y ri (t) ∈ R p i are the reference output to be tracked which could be accessed by all the agents. Note that the exosystem only disturb the i th agent which has information channel with the exosystem, i.e., E i = 0, when a i0 = 0. The regulated error e i for each subsystem is defined as
div.formula: e i (t) = y i (t) -y ri (t) = C i x i (t) + D i u i (t) -Q i ω(t), i = 1, 2, . . . , N. (14
div.p: Although we have not yet formulated the problems we study, it is evident from [41] that in any regulation problem, the following assumptions are reasonable and almost necessary.
div.formula: Assumption 4: A i -j υ I B i C i D i
div.p: has full column rank for all υ. Assumption 5: The matrix S is anti-Hurwitz-stable for continuous-time multiagent systems.

The control objective is to find the appropriate distributed control laws u i (t) to resolve the output regulation problem for all the agents and also minimize the performance. Because of the special structure of control law for the each agent, which contains the information of itself and its neighbors, this is not a standard optimal control problem.

div.head: B. Main Results
div.p: Assume that the partial agents could access the information from the exosystem directly and all the agents only access the information with its neighboring agents. Thus, distributed control law is needed. Since all the agents have different dynamics, a distributed compensator based on the exosystem inspired by the work in [42] is constructed as (15) in which η 0 represents the exosystem state ω.
div.formula: ηi (t) = Sη i (t) + α i ⎛ ⎝ N j =0 a i j (η i (t) -η j (t)) ⎞ ⎠ i = 0, 1, 2, . . . , N
div.p: If the agent i could access the information of the exosystem, i.e., a i0 > 0, then it could receive the signal of the distributed compensator as the following form:
div.formula: ηi (t) = Sη i (t) + α i ⎛ ⎝ N j =1 a i j (η i (t) -η j (t)) + a i0 (η i (t) -w(t)) ⎞ ⎠(16)
div.p: and else, a i0 = 0, and
div.formula: ηi (t) = Sη i (t) + α i ⎛ ⎝ N j =1 a i j (η i (t) -η j (t)) ⎞ ⎠ . (17
div.p: The distributed compensator could only receive information from its neighbors. Equation ( 15) could also be seen as a compensator for the i th agent. If agent i could not receive information with the exosystem, then it could receive the information of the compensator.
Consider the following equation:
div.formula: δi (t) = Sδ i (t) + α i ⎛ ⎝ N j =0 a i j (η i (t) -η j (t)) ⎞ ⎠(18)
div.p: where
div.formula: δ i (t) represents η i (t) -ω(t). Let δ(t) = (δ T 1 (t), δ T 2 (t), . . . , δ T N (t))
div.p: T , then the compact form of ( 18) could be written as
div.formula: δ(t) = (I N ⊗ S + ΛH ⊗ I q )δ(t) (19
div.p: in which Λ = block diag{α 1 , α 2 , . . . , α N }. Since the topology graph contains a spanning tree and node v 0 as its root, according to Lemma 1, the real parts of Laplacian H are positive. The eigenvalues of
div.formula: I N ⊗ S + α i H ⊗ I q are λ j (S) + α i d i , i = 1, 2, . . . , N, j = 1, 2, . . . , q.
div.p: Therefore, there exist appropriate
div.formula: α i = -{max N k=1 λ k (S) + 1}d -1
div.p: i , such that the real parts of λ i (S) + α i λ j (L ) are located in the open left half plane, i.e., δ → 0, t → ∞. Therefore, the compensator (15) could observe the information of the exosystem.
Remark 2: The digraph G contains no loop and has a spanning tree, and the nodes are labeled as i > j if (18) as the following form:
div.formula: (v i , v j ) ∈ E . Therefore, if the parameters α i = -{max N k=1 λ k (S) + 1}d -1 i , then one gets λ 1 ( H ) = λ 2 ( H ) = . . . = λ N ( H ) = -{max N k=1 λ k (S) + 1}. Rewrite
δi (t) = Sδ i (t) + α i ⎛ ⎝ N j =0 a i j (δ i (t) -δ j (t)) ⎞ ⎠ . (20
div.p: This is the other compensator such that agent i could access the information from δ i directly.
All the agents could access the information of the compensator and the distributed compensator could communicate with each other. A distributed control law is proposed as
div.formula: ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ ηi (t) = Sη i (t) + α i ⎛ ⎝ N j =0 a i j (η i (t) -η j (t)) ⎞ ⎠ δi (t) = Sδ i (t) + α i ⎛ ⎝ N j =0 a i j (δ i (t) -δ j (t)) ⎞ ⎠ u i (t) = K 1i x i (t) + K 2i η i (t) + K 3i δ i (t)(21)
div.p: in which
div.formula: α i = -{max N k=1 λ k (S) + 1}d -1 i and K 1i , K 2i , K 3i , i = 1, 2, .
div.p: . . , N are the gain matrices to be designed later.
Problem 1: Output regulation is solved for the multiagent systems (12), if an appropriate distributed control law could be found, such that the following conditions hold.

1) Internal Stability: The multiagent system ( 12) is asymptotically stable under the control law (21) without considering the disturbance state ω(t). 2) Output Regulation: For all initial conditions x i0 ∈ R n i , and ω 0 ∈ R q , all the tracking errors between measurement output and tracking reference satisfy

Problem 2: Optimal output regulation is solved if the systems not only satisfy conditions 1) and 2) in Definition 1, but also satisfy the following optimal condition. Find the appropriate gain matrices K 1i , K 2i , and K 3i , i = 1, 2, . . . , N to minimize the following infinite horizon performance indices:
div.formula: J i (x i0 , u i (t)) = ∞ 0 e i (t) T e i (t)dt, i = 1, 2, . . . , N. (23
div.p: Theorem 1: Let Assumptions 1, 4, and 5 hold, the output regulation for multiagent systems (12) is solved under the distributed law (21).
Proof: To start with, the state x i (t) in (12) and the error e i (t) could be rewritten as
div.formula: ẋi (t) = A i x i (t)+ B i u i (t)+ E i η i (t) -E i (η i (t) -ω(t)) e i (t) = C i x i (t)+ D i u i (t) -Q i η i (t)+ Q i (η i (t) -ω(t

div.p: There exist matrices ( i , i ), such that i and i are the solution of the regulator equations
div.formula: i S = A i i + B i i + E i 0 = C i i + D i i -Q i . (25
) Let xi (t) = x i (t) -i η i (t) and ũi (t) = u i (t) -i η i (t)
div.p: , then according to the regulator equations ( 25), the agents' state x i (t) and error e i (t) in ( 24) can be transformed as
div.formula: ẋi (t) = A i ( xi (t) + i η i (t)) + B i ( ũi (t) + i η i (t)) + E i η i (t) -E i (η i (t) -ω(t)) -i ηi (t) = A i xi (t) + B i ũi (t) -E i (η i (t) -ω(t)) + (A i + B i i + E i )η i (t) -i ⎛ ⎝ Sη i (t) + α i ⎛ ⎝ N j =0 a i j (η i (t) -η j (t)) ⎞ ⎠ ⎞ ⎠ = A i xi (t) + B i ũi (t) -E i δ i (t) -α i i ⎛ ⎝ N j =0 a i j (δ i (t) -δ j (t)) ⎞ ⎠ (26

e i (t) = C i ( xi (t) + i η i (t)) + D i ( ũi (t) + i η i (t)) -Q i η i (t) + D i K 2i (η i (t) -ω(t)) = C i xi (t) + D i ũi (t) + (C i i + D i i -Q i )η i (t) + Q i (η i (t) -ω(t)) = C i xi (t) + D i ũi (t) + Q i δ i (t) (27
div.p: and the control law ũi (t) has the following form:
div.formula: ũi (t) = u i (t) -i η i (t) = K 1i x i (t) + (K 2i -i )η i (t) + K 3i δ i (t). (28
div.p: The control gain matrix K 2i could be designed as follows:
div.formula: K 2i = i -K 1i i . (29
div.p: Then, one gets
div.formula: ũi (t) = K 1i x i (t) + ( i -K 1i i -i )η i (t) + K 3i δ i (t) = K 1i xi (t) + K 3i δ i (t). (30
div.p: Since α i is chosen as (19) as follows: (31) which is equivalent to
div.formula: α i = -{max N k=1 λ k (S) + 1}d -1 i , the eigenvalues of H are λ i ( H ) = λ j ( H ) = -max N k=1 λ k (S) -1. A transformation δ(t) = (U ⊗ I q )δ(t) is used on
δ(t) = I N ⊗ S + - N max k=1 λ k (S) + 1 I N ⊗ I q δ(t)

δi (t) = S - N max k=1 λ k (S) + 1 I q δi (t), i = 1, 2, . . . , N (32) in which δ(t) = ( δT 1 (t), δT 2 (t), . . . , δT N (t)) T . Design the compensator variable as δi (t) = δ j (t), δ(t) = (1 N ⊗ I q ) δi (t), i, j = 1, 2, . . . , N. Then, one gets δ i (t) = (T i ⊗ I q ) δ(t) = (T i ⊗ I q )(U -1 ⊗ I q ) δ(t) = (T i U -1 1 N ⊗ I q ) δi (t), in which T i = (0 • • • 0 1 0 • • • 0), i.e.
div.p: , the i th element of T i ∈ R 1×N is 1 and the others are zeros. Then, ( 26) and ( 27) could be rewritten as follows: (33) in which
div.formula: ẋi (t) = A i xi (t) + B i ũi (t) -Υ δi (t) e i (t) = C i xi (t) + D i ũi (t) + Q i T i U -1 1 N δi (t)
Υ i = E i (T i U -1 1 N ) + α i i (T i H U -1 1 N ),
div.p: and ũi (t) in (30) has the following forms:
div.formula: ũi (t) = K 1i xi (t) + K 3i (T i U -1 1 N ) δi (t). (34
div.p: Let X i (t) = ( x T i (t), δT i (t)) T , then according to ( 32)-( 34), one gets
div.formula: Ẋi (t) = A ic X i (t) + B ic ũi (t) e i (t) = C ic X i (t) + D ic ũi (t) (35
div.p: in which
div.formula: A ic = A i -Υ i 0 S - N max k=1 λ k (S) + 1 I q , B ic = B i 0 C c = (C i Q i (T i U -1 1 N )), D ic = D i
div.p: and the control law ũ(t) is rewritten as
div.formula: ũ(t) = K ic X i (t) (36
div.p: where
div.formula: K ic = (K 1i K 3i (T i U -1 1 N )).
div.p: Substituting the control law (36) into (35), one gets the following closed-loop system:
div.formula: Ẋi (t) = (A ic + B ic K ic )X i (t) e i (t) = (C ic + D ic K ic )X i (t). (37
div.p: The requirement of internal stability of the closed-loop system comprising of the agent i and the distributed compensator requires that the pair (A i , B i ) is stabilizable. Therefore, there exist appropriate gain matrix K 1i such that A i + B i K 1i is Hurwitz-stable. Equivalently, if the matrix S -(max N k=1 λ k (S) + 1)I q is Hurwitz, the control law (36) makes the closed-loop system (37) asymptotically stable.
According to (37), one gets
div.formula: X i (t) = e ( A ic +B ic K ic )t X i (0) e i (t) = (C ic + D ic K ic )e ( A ic +B ic K ic )t X i (0).
div.p: Since A i + B i K 1i and S-(max N k=1 λ k (S)+1)I q are Hurwitzstable, then A ic + B ic K ic is Hurwitz, and X i (t) → 0 as t → ∞, and the closed-loop system (37) is asymptotically stable. Therefore, the internal stability is finished. This completes the proof of the property that the error e i (t) tends to zero as t tends to infinity.

According to Theorem 1, output regulation for multiagent systems is solved if we find an appropriate parameter α and gain matrices K ic which make the closed-loop system (37) stable. In order to finish the optimal output regulation problem, the control gain K ic should also minimize the performance index J i (x i0 , u i (t)). The next result shows that the distributed control law (21) could finish the optimal output regulation under the directed topology graph.
Theorem 2: Under Assumptions 1, 4, and 5, optimal output regulation could be solved by the control (21), if there exists a symmetric P i > 0 satisfying
div.formula: A T ic P i + P i A ic + C T ic C ic -D T ic C ic + B T ic P i T D T ic D ic -1 D T ic C ic + B T ic P i = 0. (38
div.p: Then, the control law (21) using
div.formula: K * ic = -(D T ic D ic ) -1 (B T ic P i + D T ic C ic )
div.p: is optimal with respect to the performance index ( 23) and also solves the output regulation for multiagent systems (12).
Proof: The system dynamics and the control law could be transformed into (35) and (36). Thus, the proof is easy to be obtained and omitted.

Remark 3: Equation ( 25), known as the regulator equations, is instrumental to establish the linear output regulation theory. It can be viewed in [41] that if Assumption 4 holds, the regulator equation ( 25) must has a solution.

ADP method could be implemented easily by collecting the variable of outputs information. We only need to find initial data, then perform the online PI algorithm to obtain the optimal feedback gain. The detail algorithm will be given in Section IV.

div.head: IV. OPTIMAL OUTPUT REGULATION DESIGN
div.p: VIA ONLINE PI ALGORITHM This section aims to develop an online PI algorithm to solve the optimal output regulation problem without requiring the agents' dynamics, i.e., the information of A i , i = 1, 2, . . . , N and S is unavailable in the designing of the distributed protocols.

div.head: A. Derivation of PI Algorithm for Quadratic Cost With Cross-Product Term
div.p: From Theorem 1, we can readily find an gain matrix K ic such that all the eigenvalues of A ic + B ic K ic lie in the open left half plane. The infinite horizon quadratic cost of node i is defined as
div.formula: V (X i (t)) = ∞ t e T i (t)e i (t)dt = ∞ t X T i (t)(C ic + D ic K ic ) T (C ic + D ic K ic )X i (t)dt = X T i (t)P i X i (t) (39)
div.p: in which P i is the real symmetric positive definite solution of the Lyapunov matrix equation
div.formula: A ic + B ic K T ic P i + P i (A ic + B ic K ic ) = -(C ic + D ic K ic ) T (C ic + D ic K ic ) (40)
div.p: and V (X i (t)) could be viewed as a Lyapunov function for (35) with gain K ic . The cost function (39) can be written as
div.formula: V (X i (t)) = t +T t e T i (τ )e i (τ )dτ = t +T t X T i (τ )(C ic + D ic K ic ) T ×(C ic + D ic K ic )X i (τ )dτ + V (X i (t + T )). (41)
div.p: For an initial stabilizing gain K 1 ic , the PI algorithm iterates between the following two steps:
div.formula: X T i (t)P j i X i (t) = t +T t X T i (τ ) C ic + D ic K j ic T × C ic + D ic K j ic X i (τ )dτ + X T i (t + T )P j i X i (t + T ) K j +1 ic = -D T ic D ic -1 B T ic P j i + D T ic C ic . (42
div.p: Note that the proposed PI algorithm does not involve the plant matrix A i and I N ⊗ S + αL ⊗ I q , i.e., thus it could solve the partially model-free output regulation problem. Remark 4: ADP methods [43], [44] do provide effective online learning schemes that converge to optimal control solutions for unknown systems, where the algebra Riccati equation (ARE) is unavailable. PI [45]- [49] refers to a class of ADP algorithms built as a two-step iteration: 1) policy evaluation and 2) policy improvement. Instead of directly solving the ARE, the PI algorithm starts by evaluating the cost function of a given initial admissible controller. The cost associated with this policy is then used to obtain a new improved control policy and the algorithm is often accomplished by minimizing a Hamiltonian function with respect to the new cost. The policy evaluation and policy improvement are repeated until the actual policy obtained by the policy improvement step no longer changes, then the optimal policy is achieved.

It is seen that (42) contains P j i which is to be solved and K j ic could be obtained by the preprocess. In addition, (42) does not contain the information of A i and S. Thus, we can obtain P j i from (42) with partially model information. Note that P j i is the symmetric positive definite matrix, we can use the least-squares method to (42) for obtaining P j i . By using Kronecker product representation [50], one gets
div.formula: X T i (t)P j i X i (t) = P j i T Xi (t) (43
div.p: where X T i (t) denotes the Kronecker product quadratic polynomial basis vector with the elements {X i (t)X k (t), i = 1, 2, . . . , n i + Nq, k = 1, 2, . . . , n i + Nq}, and ( P j i ) T denotes the corresponding Kronecker product symmetric matrix vector p ik , (i = k) and 2 p ik , (i = k). Equation ( 42) could be written as
div.formula: P j i T ( Xi (t) -Xi (t + T )) = t +T t X T i (τ ) C ic + D ic K j ic T C ic + D ic K j ic X i (τ )dτ. (44
div.p: Now, assume that Xi (t) and Xi (t + T ) are evaluated M ≥ (n i + Nq)(n i + Nq + 1)/2 times as the i th iteration from the different points. For t = 1, 2, . . . , M, let
div.formula: δ i (X) t = Xi (t) -Xi (t + T ) χ i (X) t = t +T t X T i (τ ) C ic + D ic K j ic T C ic + D ic K j ic X i (τ )dτ.
div.p: Thus, one obtains
div.formula: P j i = (δδ T ) -1 δχ (45
div.p: where

The least-squares method can be solved after a number of data points are collected along a state trajectory in real-time region. The persistent excitation condition must be guaranteed in order to make P j i converge to the ideal value.

div.head: B. Convergence Analysis
div.p: Some basic lemmas will be used to establish the convergence of the proposed algorithm.
Lemma 2: If the matrix A ic + B ic K j ic is stable, the solution 42) is also the unique symmetric positive definite solution of the following Lyapunov equation:
div.formula: P j i (P j i > 0) of (
A ic + B ic K j ic T P j i + P j i A ic + B ic K j ic + C ic + D ic K j ic T C ic + D ic K j ic = 0. (46
div.p: Proof: The cost function is defined as
div.formula: V j i (X i (t)) = X T i (t)P j i X i (t). (47
div.p: For the underlying closed-loop system
div.formula: Ẋi (t) = A ic + B ic K j ic X i (t). (48
div.p: Since that the matrix A ic + B ic K j ic is stable, and
div.formula: (C ic + D ic K j ic ) T (C ic + D ic K j ic
div.p: ) > 0, according to the Lyapunov stability principle, (65) has a unique solution P j i > 0. Then, we will prove that P j i also satisfies (42). Taking the derivative of V j i (X i (t)) along the closed-loop system (48) yields
div.formula: V j i (X i (t)) = X T i (t) A ic + B ic K j ic T P j i + P j i A ic + B ic K j ic X i (t) = -X T i (t) C ic + D ic K j ic T C ic + D ic K j ic X i (t). (49
div.p: For any given T > 0, integrating both sides of (49) from t to t + T , then we obtain
div.formula: t +T t V j i (X i (τ ))dτ = - t +T t X T i (τ ) C ic + D ic K j ic T C ic + D ic K j ic X i (τ )dτ. (50
div.p: Since
div.formula: t +T t V j i (X i (τ ))dτ = X T i (t +T )P j i X i (t +T ) -X T i (t)P j i X i (t).
div.p: Thus, (50) could be computed as
div.formula: X T i (t + T )P j i X i (t + T ) -X T i (t)P j i X i (t) = - t +T t X T i (τ ) C ic + D ic K j ic T C ic + D ic K j ic X i (τ )dτ. (51
div.p: The proof is finished. Lemma 3: If the matrix A ic + B ic K j ic is stable, then the updated feedback gain matrix K j +1 ic yielded by ( 42) is still a stabilizing gain matrix.
Proof: Taking the derivative of
div.formula: V j i (X i (t)) along the closed-loop system Ẋi (t) = (A ic + B ic K j +1 ic )X i (t) yields V j i (X i (t)) = X T i (t) A ic + B ic K j +1 ic T P j i + P j i A ic + B ic K j +1 ic X i (t) = X T i (t) A ic + B ic K j ic T P j i + P j i A ic + B ic K j ic X i (t) + X T i (t) K j +1 ic -K j ic T B T ic P j ic +P j ic B ic K j +1 ic -K j ic X i (t). (52
div.p: From ( 42), the last two terms of (52) can be transformed into
div.formula: X T i (t) K j +1 ic -K j ic T B T ic P j ic + P j ic B ic K j +1 ic -K j ic X i (t) = X T i (t) K j +1 ic T B T ic P j ic + K j +1 ic T D T ic C ic -K j +1 ic T D T ic C ic + P j ic B ic K j +1 ic +C T ic D ic K j +1 ic -C T ic D ic K j +1 ic -K j ic T B T ic P j ic -K j ic T D T ic C ic + K j ic T D T ic C ic -P j ic B ic K j ic -C T ic D ic K j ic + C T ic D ic K j ic X i (t) = X T i (t) K j +1 ic T B T ic P j ic + D T ic C ic + B T ic P j ic + D T ic C ic T K j +1 ic -K j ic T B T ic P j ic + D T ic C ic -B T ic P j ic + D T ic C ic T K j ic -K j +1 ic T D T ic C ic -C T ic D ic K j +1 ic + K j ic T D T ic C ic + C T ic D ic K j ic X i (t). (53
) Since that K j +1 ic = -(D T ic D ic ) -1 (B T ic P j i + D T ic C ic ), (53
div.p: ) could be rewritten as
div.formula: X T i (t) K j +1 ic -K j ic T B T ic P j ic + P j ic B ic K j +1 ic -K j ic X i (t) = X T i (t) -K j +1 ic T D T ic D ic K j +1 ic -K j +1 ic T D T ic D ic K j +1 ic + K j ic T D T ic D ic K j +1 ic + K j +1 ic T D T ic D ic K j ic -K j +1 ic T D T ic C ic -C T ic D ic K j +1 ic + K j ic T D T ic C ic + C T ic D ic K j ic X i (t).
div.p: (54) IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON NEURAL NETWORKS AND LEARNING SYSTEMS Note that
div.formula: C ic + D ic K j +1 ic T C ic + D ic K j +1 ic = C T ic C ic + C T ic D ic K j +1 ic + K j +1 ic T D T ic C ic + K j +1 ic T D T ic D ic K j +1 ic (55) K j +1 ic -K j ic T D T ic D ic K j +1 ic -K j ic = K j +1 ic T D T ic D ic K j +1 ic -K j ic T D T ic D ic K j +1 ic -K j +1 ic T D T ic D ic K j ic + K j ic T D T ic D ic K j ic .(56)
div.p: Therefore, one gets
div.formula: X T i (t) K j +1 ic -K j ic T B T ic P j ic + P j ic B ic K j +1 ic -K j ic X i (t) = X T i (t) -C ic + D ic K j +1 ic T C ic + D ic K j +1 ic -K j +1 ic -K j ic T D T ic D ic K j +1 ic -K j ic +C T ic C ic + C T ic D ic K j ic + K j ic T D T ic C ic + K j ic T D T ic D ic K j ic X i (t) = X T i (t) -C ic + D ic K j +1 ic T C ic + D ic K j +1 ic -K j +1 ic -K j ic T D T ic D ic K j +1 ic -K j ic + C ic + D ic K j ic T C ic + D ic K j ic X i (t).(57)
div.p: According to (46), one gets
div.formula: X T i (t) A ic + B ic K j ic T P j i + P j i A ic + B ic K j ic X i (t) = -X T i (t) C ic + D ic K j ic T C ic + D ic K j ic X i (t).
div.p: (58) Submitting (57) and (58) into (52), one obtains
div.formula: V j i (X i (t)) = X T i (t) A ic + B ic K j +1 ic T P j i + P j i A ic + B ic K j +1 ic X i (t) = X T i (t) A ic + B ic K j ic T P j i + P j i A ic + B ic K j ic X i (t) + X T i (t) K j +1 ic -K j ic T B T ic P j ic +P j ic B ic K j +1 ic -K j ic X i (t). = -X T i (t) C ic + D ic K j +1 ic T C ic + D ic K j +1 ic X i (t) -X T i (t) K j +1 ic -K j ic T D T ic D ic K j +1 ic -K j ic X i (t) < 0. (59) Therefore, Ẋi (t) = (A ic + B ic K j ic )X i (t)
div.p: is the Hurwitz stable according to the Lyapunov principle.
For any stabilizing feedback control law ũi (t) = K j ic X i (t), the closed-loop system dynamic could be expressed as
div.formula: Ẋi (t) = A ic + B ic K j ic X i (t) (60)
div.p: with the solution
div.formula: X i (t) = e ( A ic +B ic K j ic )t X i (0).(61)
div.p: Then, the iterative kernel matrix P j i of the performance index (47) can be obtained as
div.formula: P j i = ∞ 0 e ( A ic +B ic K j ic ) T t C ic + D ic K j ic T × C ic + D ic K j ic e ( A ic +B ic K j ic )t dt. (62
div.p: Lemma 4: If P 1 i and P 2 i in (62) are iterative kernel matrices with respect to the iterative feedback gain matrices K 1 ic and K 2 ic , then it holds that
div.formula: P 1 i -P 2 i = ∞ 0 e ( A ic +B ic K 1 ic ) T t × K 1 ic -K 2 ic T D T ic D ic K 1 ic -K 2 ic + K 1 ic -K 2 ic T D T ic C ic + B T ic P 2 i + D T ic D ic K 2 ic + D T ic C ic + B T ic P 2 i + D T ic D ic K 2 ic T K 1 ic -K 2 ic ×e ( A ic +B ic K 1 ic )t dt(63)
div.p: or
div.formula: P 1 i -P 2 i = ∞ 0 e ( A ic +B ic K 2 ic ) T t × K 1 ic -K 2 ic T D T ic D ic K 1 ic -K 2 ic + K 1 ic -K 2 ic T D T ic C ic + B T ic P 1 i + D T ic D ic K 2 ic + D T ic C ic + B T ic P 1 i + D T ic D ic K 2 ic T K 1 ic -K 2 ic ×e ( A ic +B ic K 2 ic )t dt. (64
div.p: Proof: Define
div.formula: R P j ic = A ic + B ic K j ic T P j i + P j i A ic + B ic K j ic + C ic + D ic K j ic T C ic + D ic K j ic . (65
div.p: According to Lemma 2, P j i solves the Lyapunov equation ( 46), i.e., R(P j ic ) = 0. Then, we have
div.formula: 0 = R P 1 ic -R P 2 ic = A ic + B ic K 1 ic T P 1 i + P 1 i A ic + B ic K 1 ic + C ic + D ic K 1 ic T C ic + D ic K 1 ic -A ic + B ic K 2 ic T P 2 i + P 2 i A ic + B ic K 2 ic + C ic + D ic K 2 ic T C ic + D ic K 2 ic = A ic + B ic K 1 ic T P 1 i -P 2 i + P 1 i -P 2 i A ic + B ic K 1 ic + K 1 ic -K 2 ic T B T ic P 2 i + P 2 i B ic K 1 ic -K 2 ic + K 1 ic -K 2 ic T D T ic C ic + C T ic D ic K 1 ic -K 2 ic + K 1 ic T D T ic D ic K 1 ic -K 2 ic T D T ic D ic K 2 ic = A ic + B ic K 1 ic T P 1 i -P 2 i + P 1 i -P 2 i A ic + B ic K 1 ic + K 1 ic -K 2 ic T D T ic C ic + B T ic P 2 i + D T ic D ic K 2 ic + D T ic C ic + B T ic P 2 i + D T ic D ic K 2 ic T K 1 ic -K 2 ic + K 1 ic -K 2 ic T D T ic D ic K 1 ic -K 2 ic .
div.p: Therefore, by the similar computation of (62), P 1 i -P 2 i could be expressed as the form of (63) or (64).

Remark 5: The above three lemmas are necessary to the PI algorithm. P j i could not only be solved by Lyapunov equation (46), but also by PI algorithm (42), which does not need the system dynamics A i and S. Lemma 3 shows that if the gain K j ic is stabilizing, the gain K j +1 ic is also stabilizing.
In Lemma 4, in order to prove (64), we only need to rewrite
div.formula: R(P 1 ic ) -R(P 2 ic ) as R P 1 ic -R P 2 ic = A ic + B ic K 2 ic T P 1 i -P 2 i + P 1 i -P 2 i A ic + B ic K 2 ic + K 1 ic -K 2 ic T B T ic P 1 i + P 1 i B ic K 1 ic -K 2 ic + K 1 ic -K 2 ic T D T ic C ic + C T ic D ic K 1 ic -K 2 ic + K 1 ic T D T ic D ic K 1 ic -K 2 ic T D T ic D ic K 2 ic
div.p: and the detail process is omitted.
The underlying analysis will give the proof of the convergence.

Theorem 3: Let P j i , j = 1, 2, . . . be the solution of ( 42), and K 1 ic be an initial stabilizing control gain, then the matrix sequence P 1 i , P 2 i , P 3 i , . . . is convergent. Moreover, it converges to the solution P i of (38).

Proof: The proof is done by the mathematical induction. Since the K 1 ic is the initial control gain such that all the eigenvalues of A ic + B ic K 1 ic have negative real parts, and according to Lemma 2, P 1 i is the solution of (42) when j = 1. Let K 2 ic be updated as
div.formula: K 2 ic = -D T ic D ic -1 B T ic P 1 i + D T ic C ic . (66
div.p: It is easy to obtain that A ic + B ic K 2 ic is Hurwitz by Lemma 3. Thus, the corresponding P 2 i is the solution of (42) when j = 2. Submitting (66) into (64), one gets
div.formula: P 1 i -P 2 i = ∞ 0 e ( A ic +B ic K 2 ic ) T t K 1 ic -K 2 ic T ×D T ic D ic K 1 ic -K 2 ic e ( A ic +B ic K 2 ic )t dt ≥ 0 (67)
div.p: which is equivalent to P 1 i ≥ P 2 i , i.e., . . . P 3 i ≤ P 2 i ≤ P 1 i . The optimal control law is given as
div.formula: K * ic = -(D T ic D ic ) -1 (B T ic P i + D T ic C ic ).
div.p: According to (63), one obtains
div.formula: P j i -P i = ∞ 0 e ( A ic +B ic K j ic ) T t (K j ic -K * ic ) T ×D T ic D ic K j ic -K j ic e ( A ic +B ic K * ic )t dt ≥ 0 (68)
div.p: and the following inequation could be obtained:
div.formula: P 3 i ≤ P 2 i ≤ P 1 i ≤ P i . (69
div.p: Therefore, lim j →∞ P j i = P ∞ i , where P ∞ i satisfies (46), that is
div.formula: A T ic P ∞ i + P ∞ i A ic + C T ic C ic -D T ic C ic + B T ic P ∞ i T D T ic D ic -1 D T ic C ic + B T ic P ∞ i = 0. (70
div.p: Since P i is the unique positive definite solution, then P j i which is solved in PI process (42) converges to the solution P i of (38).

Remark 6: An initial gain matrix K 1 ic should be chosen, such that all the eigenvalues of A ic + B ic K 1 ic have negative real parts. Then, the PI algorithm could be completed. Different from the existing results, the cross-product term among the performance indices is considered in our result. The PI algorithm in [28] and [29] can be viewed as a special case of this paper.

div.head: V. EXAMPLES
div.p: In this section, we give two examples to illustrate the effectiveness of our results.

div.head: A. Numerical Simulation
div.p: In this section, a simulation example is given to demonstrate the effective of the theoretic results. Assume that the global system consists of four agents and one exosystem. The four agents have the following forms:
The output of the agents is given as
In addition, the exosystem is generated by the following command generator dynamic:
and the output is shown as
Therefore, the errors between the outputs of the agents and the reference output generated by the exosystem are written as e i (t) = y i (t)y r (t), i = 1, 2, 3, 4.

To solve the optimal output regulation of the multiagent system (71), we first solve the regulation equation ( 25), then using the transformation xi (t) = x i (t)i ω(t), and ũi (t) = u i (t)i ω(t), the multiagent system (71) and the error could be transformed into the form of ( 26) and (27).
The parameters α i in the distributed compensator are chosen as α 1 = -1, α 2 = -2/4, and α 3 = α 4 = 2.

Since the system dynamics are unknown, PI algorithm is implemented to solve the optimal problem for system (35). The date of the simulation is obtained from the iteration process every 0.01s. For demonstrating the proposed algorithm, the initial states of the systems are set as X i (t) = (0.2, -0.2 * i, 0, 0, 0.3, -0.3) T , and 600 sample points are collected to determine P j i . Therefore, the optimal control law could be obtained and the tracking errors for the agents are shown in Fig. 1. The norm of the difference between the optimal control gain and the control gain obtained by the learning algorithm is shown in Figs. 2345. The initial gain matrices are chosen K ic , i = 1, 2, 3, 4 as the zero matrices with appropriate dimensions. The optimal control gain and the control gain obtained by the PI algorithm of agent 1 are shown as We do not list all the obtained matrices for space consideration.
The proposed PI method in this paper can directly obtain the optimal synchronization controller without using the system matrices A i and S.

div.head: B. Application Example
div.p: With economic development, the penetration of renewable energy sources into the electrical networks is increasing worldwide. Controlling a potentially huge number of distributed energy resources creates a daunting new challenge for operating and controlling the network safely and efficiently. This challenge can be partially addressed by microgrids.

One important issue in microgrids is the power sharing problem, i.e., the distributed generation (DG) within the microgrids shares the total active and reactive power proportional to their ratings, which can be realized by maintaining ω i = ω j , (i = j ) and v i = v j , (i = j ), while satisfying the load demand in the network. The model shown in [51] is as follows:
div.formula: τ P i ωi = -ω i + ω d -k P i P i -P d i τ P i Vi = -V i + V d i -k Q i Q i -Q d i (73
div.p: in which τ P i ∈ R is the time constant of the low-pass filters, ω i and ω d denote the inverter frequency and the desired frequency, k P i and k Q i are the droop gains, P i , Q i and P d i , Q d i are the active and reactive power outputs of a DG and desired point, and V i and V d i are the voltage amplitudes and desired voltage amplitudes.

A distributed control strategy is used in the secondary control layer to restore the frequency and voltage to their nominal values, our secondary controller is applied locally with communication with its neighboring controllers. We add the secondary control inputs into the primary control model (73) in the following form:
div.formula: τ P i ωi = -ω i + ω d -k Pi P i -P d i + u ω i τ P i Vi = -V i + V d i -k Q i Q i -Q d i + u V i (74
div.p: in which u ω i and u V i are the secondary frequency and voltage control input. The objective is to design appropriate distributed control law, such that the outputs of the voltages converge to the target voltage. The main utility grid can be viewed as the exosystem, which has been shown in Fig. 6, and the reference voltage and frequency values are known to ω e = 100π and V e = 220 V. Let u i = (u ωT i , u V T i ) T , and the parameters are given as τ p 1 = 0.016, τ p 2 = 0.016, and τ p 3 = 0.016. The desired frequency and voltage ω d = 100π and V d 1 = V d 2 = V d 3 = 220 V. P 1 = P 2 = P 3 = 0.01.
div.formula: P d 1 = P d 2 = P d 3 = 0, Q d i = Q d 2 = Q d 3 = 0.
div.p: The simulation results based on secondary frequency and voltage control input are shown in Fig. 7 that the trajectories voltage converge to reference voltage. This actually makes sense as our scheme ensures the convergence within finite time.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: This paper has brought together cooperative control, online PI algorithm to solve the output regulation for partially modelfree agents by using ADP and double compensator method. All the agents have different dimensions and the states information could not transmit with each others. Thus, we have to use a distributed compensator to overcome this problem. The controller is designed only for the case when the exosystem only disturbs the i th agent which can have access to the exosystem, and the output regulation method has been used to track the reference and reject the disturbance. A distributed control law has been obtained to solve the problem. At last, the gain matrices have been obtained by PI algorithm instead of the traditional optimal control method. Two examples have been shown to illustrate the effectiveness of the results.

In addition, there still exist some other interesting problems that need to be addressed, such as optimal output regulation for unknown nonlinear multiagent systems, which deserves further investigation.

div.p: This work was supported in part by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant 61433004, in part by the Integrated Automation of Process Industry Fundamental Research Funds under Grant 2013ZCX14, and in part by the Development Project through the Key Laboratory of Liaoning Province.
His current research interests include approximate dynamic programming, inverse optimal control, and multiagent systems. Dr. Feng is a Reviewer of the IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON AUTOMATIC CONTROL.
